channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-4022] osgi:reference workaround for bundle startup problems in fabric profiles no longer works in Fuse 6.2
item.description:
When a Camel route is specified using Spring XML, as part of a profile to be deployed in fabric, in the past it has proven necessary to add an <osgi:reference> definition to the Spring configuration, to ensure that application components do not start up before system ones (ActiveMQ, CXF). For ActiveMQ, for example, a typical formuation was:

<osgi:reference id="amqcomp" interface="org.apache.camel.spi.ComponentResolver" filter="(component=amq)" cardinality="1..1"/>

This formulation no longer works in Fuse 6.2, so applications fail to start more often than not. A workaround is to remove and re-add the application's profile to the container after it has started, but this is inconvenient.
item.summary: osgi:reference workaround for bundle startup problems in fabric profiles no longer works in Fuse 6.2

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Kevin Boone Did you check with blueprint routes?

Hmm, I checked your example in 6.2.1.redhat-083 and I've simply used:

<camelContext id="example-context" xmlns="http://camel.apache.org/schema/spring" useMDCLogging="true" trace="false" depends-on="amqComponent">

and several child container restarts didn't show the problem (it was visible without depends-on="amqComponent").

Kevin Boone, resolving as "rejected" for now, as IMO the workaround is simple. And it should work in 6.2.0.GA too, because we didn't change anything related to spring-dm.

If you think it should be resolved differently, please reopen.
osgi:reference is giving you "amq" bean in spring(-dm) application context, it has to stay there.

Experiencing bundle startup problems with the 'camel-spring' component bundle itself where using the workaround of updating the spring xml file doesn't apply. It appears that after a 'fabric:create' on a clean install the bundle levels for most if not all the camel components are the same as what user added bundles are.
Kevin Boone do you still check the same project (like the one attached?) or do you use other example?
Linking with Camel Blueprint - depends-on does not work. Kevin Boone could this be your problem?
Fair enough. As I said, I'm happy to try some sort of test patch for that, if there is one. I think it's going to be a bit awkward in a fabric set-up, however. You're the expert, of course.
Hmm, I wasn't able to reproduce it anymore on 6.2.1.redhat-083...
Closing, as workaround with setting SL="81" works on Fuse 6.2.

In 6.1 the situation is a bit different. spring-extender, mq-fabric and example-adapter starts at level 60 (child container). Those bundles are sorted like in 6.2, so spring-extender starts last - and only then it checks previously installed bundle (like example-adapter) and starts OSGi Spring contexts. At this time, org.fusesource.mq.fabric.camel.AMQComponentResolver is ready to resolve "amq" component.

The key seem to be definition of spring-dm feature:

    <feature name="spring-dm" description="Spring DM support" version="1.2.1" resolver="(obr)">
 
        <feature version="[2.5.6,4)">spring</feature>
 
        <bundle dependency="true" start-level="30">mvn:org.apache.servicemix.bundles/org.apache.servicemix.bundles.cglib/2.2.2_1</bundle>
 
        <bundle start-level="30">mvn:org.springframework.osgi/spring-osgi-io/1.2.1</bundle>
 
        <bundle start-level="30">mvn:org.springframework.osgi/spring-osgi-core/1.2.1</bundle>
 
        <bundle start-level="30">mvn:org.springframework.osgi/spring-osgi-extender/1.2.1</bundle>
 
        <bundle start-level="30">mvn:org.springframework.osgi/spring-osgi-annotation/1.2.1</bundle>
 
        <bundle start-level="30">mvn:org.apache.karaf.deployer/org.apache.karaf.deployer.spring/2.3.0.redhat-610379</bundle>
 
    </feature>

When this feature is installed in Fuse 6.1:

  • on root container it is installed by karaf's feature service before creating fabric, so start-level is honoured
  • after fabric creation, root container has this feature already installed, fabric-agent doesn't change this start level at all
  • on child container, spring-dm feature is installed by fabric-agent only - without taking into account start level (Guillaume Nodet, Freeman(Yue) Fang please confirm!)
  • so the order in Fuse 6.1 is: example-adapter, mq-fabric, spring-extender. Only when spring-extender is started, example-adapter's OSGi Spring context is refreshed. AMQComponent resolver is already available

In Fuse 6.2, fabric-agent supports start level, but only specified in <bundle> element

  • so the order in Fuse 6.2 is: spring-extender started at SL=30, example-adapter, mq-fabric (both on SL=80). example-adapter's OSGi Spring context may already be processed (because spring-extender is ready), thus we have race condition between example-adapter and mq-fabric

There's issue in Karaf 4 (which deployer is used in fabric-agent in Fuse 6.2): https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KARAF-4155. It's fixed by actually taking into account @start-level atribute specified at <feature> level. I'll backport it to Fuse 6.2.1 patch and 6.3. But because camel-amq feature is defined like this:

    <feature name="camel-amq" version="1.2.0.redhat-621083" resolver="(obr)">
 
        <feature version="1.2.0.redhat-621083">mq-fabric</feature>
 
        <feature version="5.11.0.redhat-621083">activemq-client</feature>
 
        <feature version="[2.14,3)">camel-jms</feature>
 
        <feature version="[2.14,3)">camel</feature>
 
        <bundle>mvn:org.apache.activemq/activemq-camel/5.11.0.redhat-621083</bundle>
 
        <bundle>mvn:io.fabric8.mq/camel-amq/1.2.0.redhat-621083</bundle>
 
    </feature>

it (this backport) won't change the start level of camel-amq bundle (it'll be default == 80 in Fuse 6.2). It will however make camel-spring bundle start at level 50:

  <feature name='camel-spring' version='2.15.1.redhat-621083' resolver='(obr)' start-level='50'>
 
    <bundle dependency='true'>mvn:org.apache.geronimo.specs/geronimo-jta_1.1_spec/1.1.1</bundle>
 
    <feature version='[3.2,4)'>spring</feature>
 
    <feature version='[1.2,2)'>spring-dm</feature>
 
    <feature version='[3.2,4)'>spring-tx</feature>
 
    <feature version='2.15.1.redhat-621083'>camel-core</feature>
 
    <bundle>mvn:org.apache.camel/camel-spring/2.15.1.redhat-621083</bundle>
 
  </feature>
Roddie Kieley I'm assigning to you - please check if the above explanation is fine.

Grzegorz Grzybek thank you for the very detailed root cause analysis of the problem and identifying the open issue in Karaf, it is indeed a good explanation. Given the Karaf issue I have opened ENTESB-4809, linked, to have the work for the back port of KARAF-4155 tracked properly.
Hmm, I think everything is ready for a patch, especially this commit: https://github.com/jboss-fuse/fabric8/commit/934e7f98bc7239ebafa7e3c9ad62106175398c2c

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
1. Unpack, build, and deploy the project in attached example.zip
2. Install Fuse 6.2
3. fabric:create
4. profile-import mvn:com.example/example-profile/1.0.0-SNAPSHOT/zip/profile
5. container-create-child --profile mq-client-default --profile example-adapter.test --version 1.0 root example-child
6. When child container has started, container-connect to it, and check using "camel:route-list" that the Camel route has started
7. Stop the child container
8. Start the child container
9. Note that the Camel route no longer starts, and the child container log shows

org.apache.camel.RuntimeCamelException: org.apache.camel.FailedToCreateRouteException: Failed to create route example-route: Route(example-route)[[From[amq:queue:logging.event]] -> [pro... because of Failed to resolve endpoint: amq://queue:logging.event due to: No component found with scheme: amq

10. container-remove-profile example-child example-adapter.test
11. container-add-profile example-child example-adapter.test
12. Note that the Camel route in the child container has now started
